Award.AwardTitle: Chemical, Electrochemical and Physical Properties of Metallosupramolecular Architectures with Tetrazine Based Ligands Including Investigations of Anion-pi Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Kim Dunbar of the Texas A&M University will study various aspects of anion-pi interactions: anion interactions with aromatic molecules. The goals are to study metal complexes with ligands containing electropositive tetrazine rings that form unusual molecular ring assemblies including five-membered pentagons exhibiting high stabilities in solution and remarkable flexibility that allows them to be easily converted to other ring sizes by the addition of different anions. Another goal is to study chemical reactions triggered by the capture or release of anions which may be a way to alter the physical and chemical properties of the assemblies. Data from solid-state, solution, gas phase and computational studies will be used to assess the strength of anion-pi forces and to assist in future experiments aimed at predicting structures. One application of this research will be to design very large polyhedral molecules by using the five-membered ring molecules as building blocks. Another application will be to construct molecular magnets by taking advantage of the ease of reduction of tetrazine ligands to prepare organic radicals that can act as bridges between paramagnetic metal ions. The broader impacts of the research include graduate student and postdoctoral researcher training in the chemical sciences, efforts to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in chemical science research, and outreach to local museums and science fairs in order to enhance scientific and technological understanding. The versatility of skills required to work on the project presents an excellent opportunity for students to learn about a broad spectrum of research disciplines.

In this project the assembly of organic molecules and metal ions will be harnessed to promote the formation of large geometric structures that often can display unusual properties useful for applications. This work will expand the repertoire of chemistry that can be used to create magnetic and conducting materials starting with molecular components. The results of these studies could have many important long term impacts on a variety of applications in which magnetic materials are important, including non-volatile memory and spintronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant led to major outcomes in the understanding of the anion-pi interaction which is a recenlty recognized important supramolecular interaction. Our studeis have resulted in the isolation and characterization of a large number of new transition metal and rare earth compounds, many with entirely novel structures for neutral and radical bridged molecules including pentagons and triangles in addtion to linear molecules and squares. The magnetic and electrochemical properties of many of these compounds reveal extremely strong coupling between spin centers and and single molecule magnet behavior. SMMs behave analogously to traditional magnets in that they retain a preferential direction of the magnetic moment and exhibit magnetic hysteresis, i.e., a memory effect. Unlike bulk magnets, however, the magnetic properties of SMMs are molecular in origin; an isolated single molecule behaves like a tiny bar magnet. We also learned how to independently conduct calculations at many different levels including ab intio to introduce the anion-pi concept to a wider audience. We reached out to colleagues in physical organic computational chemistry, biochemistry and informatics to explore the existence of anion-pi interactions in nature.  Some key achievements in the previous grant period are summarized below:

- Discovered methods for reliably isolating stable radical bridged molecules with the same ligands that were studied for the anion-π interactions. A major result in the area of rare earth chemistry was the isolation the first dilanthanide complexes bridged by a radical tetrazine ligand. A comparison between the magnetic behavior of the two compounds reveals strikingly different behavior. It is very exciting to be able to test the hypothesis that merely installing a spin on a bridging ligand can have such a profiund effect. In terms of transition metal chemistry, an important discovery in this vein is the isolation of a Co3 triangle and a Co4 square from the same reaction by using supramolecular solvent interactions to tune the ring size.

 - Isolation of the first example of a dinuclear vanadium (III) radical bridged complex, with the highest ever antiferromagnetic coupling reported for any molecule.

 - Isolation of the first lanthanide molecular triangle with radical bridging ligands

 - Elaboration of models that allow for predictive approaches to preparing metallacycles with the appropriate size and shape of anion for maximizing anion-π interactions.

 - Elaboration of a predictive model for binding of inhibitors in one of the key enzymes in the cycle of infection of the Tuberculosis Bacterium disease. This model allows for more efficient drug design by taking into account the important, and previously unrecognized, role of anion-π interactions in the binding pocket.

The PI has delivered 15 lectures on this research including talks as a Keynote, Invited or Plenary speaker at conferences and Universities. Numerous other invited talks or posters on the topic of this research were given by the co-PI Dunbar and her students at ACS conferences.  The PI has been active in conferences and symposia that highlight this NSF-sponsored research and serves on the Division of Inorganic Executive Committee of the ACS and is a faculty mentor for the NOBCChE chapter on campus.The TAMU chapter won the Presidential Award for Service to NOBCChE and the STEM Community at the 42nd Annual "Bridging Generations Through STEM" Conference, Orlando, Florida in 2015. She has participated in the NASA SHARP summer high school apprenticeship program and serves as a local mentor for the ACS Minority Scholarship program. She recruits and mentors women and minorities and currently has two minority students, one of whom is a Louis Stokes Minority Fellow. Dunbar mentored 23 graduate students, 16 postdoctoral or visiting scholars and ten undergraduates during the grant period, including fourteen women and seven minorities; thirteen Ph.D.’s were awarded to Dunbar students during the funding period, including two PhD.’s whose dissertations include results from this NSF project. During this gratn period, Dunbar and her group have designed and performed demonstrations for over 1000 children during National Chemistry week including comcepts from this funded grant, visited local middle schools and served as coaches for the Chemistry Olympiad and judged science competitions.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2018
Modified by: Kim Dunbar
